bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, March 10, 1954

div1.p: Hench informs Cornelia Kean about Truby's death. He thanks her for her help with his questionnaire. He mourns for Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, March 10, 1954
div1.opener:
March 10, 1954
Mrs. J. R. Kean
2804 N Street N.W.
Georgetown
Washington 7, D.C.
My dear Mrs. Kean:
div1.p:
I assume you got my telegram of the other day with the sad message re-
garding General Truby. He has been recovering well from his stroke of
three years ago but apparently developed a coronary about two weeks ago
and passed away.

I stayed an extra day in Washington as I had a chance to visit Mrs.
Carroll and see her husband's material. This is a fantastic story
and I will send you the description of it soon.

Meanwhile, permit me to express my sincere appreciation of your help
in the matter of the questionnaire. I know that Robert will un-
doubtedly be helpful. I do not want you bothering about handwritten
notes or answers and my friend and former secretary. Miss Dorma Sohnurr,
has always been so helpful in this matter. She will call you and make
a date to see you at your mutual convenience and see whether she can
help in taking down some of your answers.

All the time I feel so distressed at the loss of General Kean and now
General Truby. Mrs. Carroll loaned me a few items that I know would be
of tremendous interest to General Kean and General Truby and it dis-
turbs me no end that I cannot continue to have their wonderful friend-
ship and counsel. But I shall keep on and surely complete the book which,
in many ways, will be not only in memory of yellow fever but in memory
of my own wonderful friends who helped me so much.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
